block.p: AN INQUIRY ON WALL STREET -- The Securities and Exchange Commission is examining whether Wall Street bank employees have been leaking information about big trades to their favored clients like hedge funds as a way to curry favor with those clients. [Page A1.]

PRESIDENT PROPOSES A BUDGET -- President Bush's spending proposal for the fiscal year that begins on Oct. 1, the first he has submitted to a Democratic Congress, calls for big increases in military spending. [A1.]

NBC UNIVERSAL TO PROMOTE ZUCKER -- When Jeff Zucker, who began at NBC as a part-time sports researcher, is named chief executive for NBC Universal today, one of the biggest questions he will face relates to the digital upheaval in the media marketplace and the financial issues accompanying it. [C1.]

MOVIES FROM WALMART.COM -- Wal-Mart has formed a partnership with top Hollywood studios to sell digital movies and television shows on its Web site. Not only is it the first traditional retailer to do that, but its penchant for low prices could drive down the cost of a digital download. [C1.]
PEACE BETWEEN THE APPLES -- Apple, the maker of the iPods, and Apple Corps, the guardian of the Beatles' music interests, have settled differences over their names and apple logos. [C1.]

NEW CHARGES FOR EX-YUKOS CHIEF -- Russian prosecutors have brought new charges of embezzlement and money laundering against Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, left, the imprisoned former chief of the Yukos oil company and one of his business partners, Platon A. Lebedev. opening a new line of legal attack against a Kremlin opponent. [C8.]

AND A GAIN FOR THE KREMLIN -- The criminal charges filed against former leaders of the Yukos oil company offer the Russian government a chance to strengthen control over the company while making the previous former leaders look bad. [A10.]

BELUGA CAVIAR BAN IS LIFTED -- A year-old international ban by a United Nations agency on the export of beluga caviar, the delicacy harvested largely by Caspian Sea countries, is over despite the objections of some marine scientists. [A5.]

ICAHN BIDS FOR LEAR -- Carl C. Icahn has offered to acquire the entire Lear Corporation, offering $36 a share in cash, which values the auto parts maker at about $2.4 billion -- almost 4 percent more than Lear's closing price of $34.67 on Friday. In Novermber, Mr. Icahn bought nearly 8.7 million shares for $23 each, according to regulatory filings. [C2.]

RESTITUTION IN BOSTON -- The Turner Broadcasting System and a Manhattan marketing agency will pay $2 million in restitution and other costs for a Cartoon Network advertising campaign that raised fears of terrorism last week. [A15.]

NO WAY TO TREAT A FLIER -- On Dec. 29, 2006, American Airlines passengers on three loaded jets in Dallas were delayed by thunderstorms. While they waited for hours, they had to endure fouled toilets and air, a shortage of food and water and a dearth of information from the airline. On the Road: Joe Sharkey. [C1.]

REVERSAL OF FORTUNE -- Usually, it is Indian companies that are taken over by foreign companies. But India was celebrating last week after the Tata Group, an Indian conglomerate, won the bidding for the Corus Group, the British-Dutch steel company, for $11.3 billion, the largest acquisition ever by an Indian company. [C10.]

EXECUTIVES OUT AT DISCOVERY -- A management revamping that resulted in the departure of two top executives at Discovery Communications gives a new hands-on role to the chief executive, David M. Zaslav, a former NBC Universal executive who joined the company in December. [C10.]

REALLY, IT's JUST A MUPPET -- All Dan Victor, an executive at Sesame Workshop, wanted to do was include in his checked baggage the head of a lion to be used in the Indian version of Sesame Street. Frequent Flier. [C4.]
VISA WOES -- Foreign executives are complaining about the visa requirements for entry into the United States, saying the process deters travel to the United States. [C4.]
ONLINE

DYING PINES, DYING BEARS -- The question of what grizzly bears eat, how much of it will be available in the future, and where may hinge on the mountain pine beetle and the whitebark pine. An audio slide show is at nytimes.com/science.

Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.
JANUS CAPITAL GROUP, the asset manager, said that its chief financial officer, Dave R. Martin, and general counsel, John H. Bluher, were leaving the firm in unrelated departures. (REUTERS)
THE CHEVRON CORPORATION announced yesterday that it would separate the positions of chief executive and board chairman and make it easier for shareholders to remove directors. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)
